text: And Abram said, Lord GOD, what wilt thou give me, seeing I go childless, and the steward  of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus?
text_kjv: And Abram said, Lord GOD, what wilt thou give me, seeing I go childless, and the steward  of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus?
text_niv: But Abram said, “O Sovereign Lord, what can you give me since I remain childless and the one who will inherit my estate is Eliezer of Damascus?”
text_esv: But Abram said, “O Lord GOD, what will you give me, for I continue  childless, and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?”
text_nlt: But Abram replied, “O Sovereign LORD, what good are all your blessings when I don’t even have a son? Since you’ve given me no children, Eliezer of Damascus, a servant in my household, will inherit all my wealth.
text_msg: Abram said, "God, Master, what use are your gifts as long as I'm childless and Eliezer of Damascus is going to inherit everything?"
text_nasb: Abram said, 'O Lord GOD, what will You give me, since I am childless, and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?'
context: In Abram's time, lineage and descendants were of paramount importance. A man's legacy lived on through his children, ensuring the continuation of his name, property, and tribal affiliations. Childlessness was a significant source of shame and insecurity, often interpreted as a sign of divine disfavor. The Ancient Near East culture placed immense value on large families, viewing them as a blessing from the gods and a source of economic and social strength. Abram's wealth, accumulated through his journey from Ur and his success in Canaan, held less significance without an heir to inherit it. Inheritance laws generally favored biological sons; adoption was an option, but typically reserved for those without any direct descendants. Abram's reference to Eliezer, his steward, highlights the desperation for an heir. Stewards managed households and possessions, often having considerable authority, but they were not blood relatives. Abram's concern wasn't merely about earthly inheritance but about the fulfillment of God's promises – promises of land and numerous descendants. Without a child, those promises seemed unattainable. His phrasing “Lord GOD” (Adonai Yahweh) is significant. Adonai denotes sovereignty and authority, while Yahweh is God's personal covenant name revealed to humanity. This suggests Abram is addressing God not just as a powerful being, but as the one who has entered into a personal covenant with him, making His promise all the more critical. The verse reflects the tension between human expectations and divine promises in the cultural context of the time.
meaning: Abram's question reveals a deep-seated anxiety and perhaps a hint of doubt, despite his faith in God. He directly addresses God, acknowledging both His sovereignty ("Lord") and covenant faithfulness ("GOD"). The phrase "what wilt thou give me" suggests Abram's growing impatience. He has already been promised descendants (Genesis 12:2, 13:16), and yet, years later, he remains childless. This question isn't necessarily a challenge to God's authority but an expression of vulnerability and a yearning for clarity. Abram recognizes the apparent contradiction between God's promise and his present reality. The mention of Eliezer is crucial. In the absence of a biological son, Abram considers adopting Eliezer as his heir, which was a culturally acceptable practice. However, this also reveals a potential misunderstanding of God's plan. Abram might be tempted to take matters into his own hands and fulfill the promise through human means, rather than waiting for God's intervention. This highlights a crucial theological point: God's promises are fulfilled in His timing and in His way, not necessarily according to human expectations. Abram's statement underscores the tension between faith and doubt, the struggle to reconcile God's word with earthly circumstances. This verse also foreshadows the importance of Isaac, the child of promise, who will be born miraculously through God's power, not through human efforts. Abram's frank honesty with God serves as a model for believers to express their doubts and anxieties while holding on to faith.
application: Genesis 15:2 speaks powerfully to the modern believer wrestling with unfulfilled promises or seemingly unanswered prayers. Like Abram, we often find ourselves questioning God when His plans don't align with our expectations or timelines. This verse encourages us to bring our doubts and anxieties to God in honest and vulnerable prayer. It is okay to express our frustrations and ask “Why?” or “When?” God is not intimidated by our questions, but rather invites us into deeper relationship through them. The verse highlights the importance of patience and trusting in God's timing. Just as Abram had to wait for the fulfillment of God's promise of descendants, we too may have to wait for God to answer our prayers or fulfill His purposes in our lives. This requires us to resist the temptation to take matters into our own hands, to rely on our own wisdom or efforts to achieve our desired outcomes. Instead, we must learn to trust in God's sovereignty and His ability to work all things together for good. Consider the 'Eliezer' in your own life. What are the practical, logical, seemingly easy solutions to your problems that would require you to compromise your faith? Often, God's plans are not the most obvious or convenient, but they are always the best. This verse also challenges us to examine our understanding of success and legacy. In a world that often equates success with material possessions or worldly achievements, Abram's story reminds us that true legacy lies in faithfulness to God and the fulfillment of His promises. Ultimately, this verse calls us to surrender our desires and expectations to God's will, trusting that He knows what is best for us, even when we cannot see the full picture. We are to pray earnestly and honestly, but remain faithful while we wait on His timing.
prayer: Lord God, sovereign and faithful, I come before you with a heart that echoes Abram's. I confess that sometimes I struggle to reconcile Your promises with my present reality. Like Abram, I long for fulfillment, for answers, for evidence of Your hand at work in my life. Forgive me for my impatience and my doubts. Help me to trust in Your timing and Your ways, even when they differ from my own. Give me the strength to resist the temptation to take matters into my own hands, to rely on my own understanding rather than Your divine wisdom. Fill me with faith and perseverance as I wait upon You. Help me to see the 'Eliezers' in my life; the logical solutions that may not be the God-ordained solutions. May Your will be done, and Your purposes be fulfilled in my life, for Your glory. Amen.

faqs.answer: Abram's use of both 'Lord' (Adonai) and 'GOD' (Yahweh) is significant. 'Adonai' acknowledges God's sovereignty and authority, while 'Yahweh' emphasizes His personal covenant relationship with Abram. It reflects a recognition of God's power and His commitment to His promises.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does Abram call God both 'Lord' and 'GOD'?

faqs.answer: In ancient Near Eastern cultures, lineage was crucial. Children ensured the continuation of the family name, property, and legacy. Childlessness was often viewed as a sign of divine disfavor and brought shame upon the individual and family.
faqs.question: Q2: Why was being childless such a big deal in Abram's time?

faqs.answer: Eliezer was Abram's trusted steward, likely responsible for managing his household and possessions. In the absence of a biological heir, Eliezer was potentially Abram's chosen successor to inherit his wealth and responsibilities.
faqs.question: Q3: Who was Eliezer of Damascus?

faqs.answer: Abram's question reveals a mixture of faith and doubt. While he trusts in God's promise, he also expresses anxiety and frustration over the lack of fulfillment, demonstrating the human struggle to reconcile faith with reality.
faqs.question: Q4: What does Abram's question tell us about his faith at this point?

faqs.answer: While Abram considered adopting Eliezer, the New Testament speaks of God adopting believers into His family. God’s promise to Abram was not adoption, but a biological heir. This adoption is not like Abram’s choice of Eliezer; it is a spiritual transformation and inheritance through Christ.
faqs.question: Q5: How does this verse relate to the New Testament concept of adoption into God's family?
